intro: Melanthesopsis variabilis var. vulgaris, commonly known as the common melanthus, is a herbaceous plant native to temperate regions of Europe. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring lanceolate leaves with serrated edges and a distinctive, branched inflorescence. The flowers are small and clustered, usually in shades of pink or purple, and bloom in late spring to early summer. It prefers well-drained soils and full to partial sunlight, making it a common sight in meadows and along roadsides. This plant is also noted for its use in traditional herbal medicine.
